content.title: Venous System: Structure and Function
content.summary: Veins return deoxygenated blood from tissues to the heart. They have thinner walls than arteries, lower pressure, and contain valves to prevent retrograde flow.

wall_characteristics.comparison_to_arteries: Thinner walls, less smooth muscle, larger lumen diameter
wall_characteristics.pressure: Low pressure system (5-10 mmHg in extremity veins)
wall_characteristics.capacitance: Contain 60-70% of total blood volume, act as blood reservoir

venous_types.characteristics: Run parallel to arteries, primary venous return pathway
Located above deep fascia, accessible for IV access and bypass grafts
Connect superficial to deep system, contain valves directing flow deep

valve_anatomy.structure: Bicuspid valves with thin fibrous cusps
valve_anatomy.function: Prevent retrograde flow, especially important in lower extremity
valve_anatomy.clinical_significance: Valve incompetence leads to chronic venous insufficiency and varicosities

content.clinical_significance: Venous pathology includes deep vein thrombosis, chronic venous insufficiency, and varicose veins

definition.@value: Low-pressure blood vessels that return deoxygenated blood to the heart, containing valves to prevent retrograde flow

learning_objectives: Describe the structural differences between veins and arteries
Explain the mechanisms of venous return
Identify the deep, superficial, and perforating venous systems
Relate valve dysfunction to chronic venous insufficiency
clinical_pearls: Veins contain 60-70% of total blood volume - major capacitance vessels
Perforator valves direct blood from superficial to deep system
The great saphenous vein is the most common conduit for bypass grafts
Calf muscle pump failure is key to post-thrombotic syndrome development
Normal venous pressure at ankle is <10 mmHg when walking
